awd_titl_txt: Building Quantitative Skills in Biology: An Equity-Sensitive Quantitative Biology Course via Multiple Institutions
awd_abstract_narration:
Math anxiety is disproportionately felt by women and women disproportionately report lower self-efficacy in math.  Women are also less likely than men to finish STEM-required calculus sequences, and surveys suggest this difference is driven by lower confidence rather than lower preparation or ability.  This project seeks to create an exportable and equity-sensitive quantitative biology course that minimizes math-associated inequities. This course will be taught and informed by a diverse set of institutions. The institutions include a four-year university (University of Washington), two-year colleges (North Seattle College and Shoreline Community College), and a prison education program (University Beyond Bars). This project will examine whether or not this new course decreases math-associated inequities. The course will be freely shared with the broader community so that it can be implemented or adapted by other institutions.

This project will develop a new equity-sensitive quantitative biology course, implement the course at four institutions, and assess the course for student achievement and equity in performance and affect. Development of this quantitative biology course will be guided by "Vision and Change" principles. The course structure and content will be designed to promote equity by incorporating evidence-based techniques to mitigate gender and cultural biases. The course development will be informed by its implementation at the four institutions, which differ in student demographics, type of institution, and resources. Pre- and post-course performance and affect in applied quantitative skills will be collected and analyzed. Data will also be gathered from life science students who have taken the traditional quantitative skills requirements, typically through mathematics departments. By comparing performance of students taking this new course to students taking traditional courses, the project seeks to gather evidence on the impact of incorporating quantitative skills into the life sciences. The project will also investigate the impact on minimizing math-associated inequities among students. The course materials, modules, and gap-mitigation techniques will be freely disseminated.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The need for applied quantitative skills is increasing in the life sciences, in the labor pool in general, and in society at large. Biology programs have recently—and laudably—responded by creating integrated math-biology resources. However, the potential for math-associated inequities to hitchhike into math-focused life science courses is concerning, especially because the life sciences are a relative oasis of belonging for under-represented groups in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields. More concerningly, these under-represented-in-STEM groups are the same groups which some prior studies suggest are negatively affected by math-associated biases in skills and affect. To promote equity in employment and informed civic engagement, we must teach applied quantitative skills equitably.

This project helps identify and combat barriers to ensure modern life science classrooms are welcoming to all, and aims to furnish a model for transforming gatekeeper courses into gateway experiences. In particular we: (1) examine the interplay between quantitative affect (math interest, math anxiety, math importance), STEM interest (life science vs physical science), and student demography (gender, URM status, and first-generation status), (2) create an exportable quantitative biology course that meets the recommendations of Vision and Change, yet is pedagogically sensitive to the potential biases that may arise in a math-focused life science course, and (3) assess whether the novel course works, and for whom.

To achieve the first aim of examining the interplay between quantitative affect, STEM interest, and student demography, we collected data from STEM students (n=1394) from one 4-year school and three 2-year schools. We used this data to test hypotheses on why, among STEM fields, biology has the highest proportion of students from underrepresented-in-STEM groups, and whether biology students have similar quantitative skills and affect as non-biology STEM students. The results of this aim were shared at a national conference on biology education, and are being published.

To achieve the second aim of creating an exportable quantitative biology course that meets the recommendations of Vision and Change, yet is pedagogically sensitive to the potential biases that may arise in a math-focused life science course, we established course-level learning objectives from the BioCore and BioSkills guides, used backward design to create content geared towards those learning objectives, structured the course to promote equity in performance and affect by using best practices in pedagogy, listed the course at one 4-year institution and two 2-year institutions, and iteratively revised the course based on feedback during the implementations.

To achieve the third aim of assessing whether the novel course works, and for whom, we collected pre- and post-course data for all students enrolled in the novel course, and analyzed whether the course boosted quantitative skills and/or attitudes towards math, with a focus on which student traits (eg, high anxiety towards math upon entering the course) predicted the course’s impact. The results of this aim will be published separately.

This project tested an element of potential uniqueness of life science students among the broader STEM body, illuminated existing disparities in affect towards math among life science students, created an exportable quantitative biology course, enrolled diverse students in that course, and generated data to help life science programs make evidence-based decisions on how to impart quantitative skills to their students effectively and equitably. This project aims to ensure that the infusion of quantitative skills into the life sciences will be effective and lead to empowerment.

 


Last Modified: 03/14/2025
Modified by: Jacob D Cooper
